topic.summary: A top-level DITA topic (a self-contained chunk of content).
tips: Keep topics focused: one purpose per topic.

title.summary: A title (usually the visible heading for a topic/section).
tips: Write it like a heading: short, specific, noun-first if possible.

shortdesc.summary: A short description that summarizes the topic for previews/search results.
tips: Aim for 1–2 sentences. It's not a second introduction.

body.summary: The main content container of a topic.
tips: Use sections/lists/steps for structure instead of long paragraphs.
Prefer short paragraphs. If it has multiple ideas, split it.

section.summary: A logical section inside a topic.
tips: Give sections a <title> when readers need navigation.
Keep list items parallel (same grammatical form).
Use when sequence matters; otherwise use <ul>.
One main idea per list item; avoid walls of text.

steps.summary: A container for a procedure (step-by-step instructions).
tips: Each step should be a single action the user can do.

cmd.summary: The command/action within a DITA step.
tips: Keep it short; put explanations in <info> or following text.

info.summary: Extra information that supports a step (context, explanation).
tips: Use for 'why' or constraints, not extra actions.

xref.summary: A cross-reference (link) to another topic or location.
tips: Use meaningful link text; avoid 'click here'.

codeblock.summary: A block of code or terminal output.
tips: Preserve spacing. Mention expected output if it matters.
Use warnings sparingly; they lose impact if overused.

fig.summary: A figure container (image/diagram) with optional title/desc.
tips: Add alt-like text via <desc> so it's accessible.

image.summary: An image reference (points to a file).
tips: Ensure the image has a clear purpose and caption/description if needed.
